title: Akali's shroud is one of the worst abilities ever designed
body:
Along with Yasuo's windwall and Zoe's W. 

This ability has LITERALLY zero counterplay, all you can do is wait for Akali to show herself or try to run away.
It covers a big ass radius, has its duration EXTENDED every time Akali enters stealth and provides stealth AND untargetability for a very long time if we consider what kind of game League is. And let's not forget that if Akali attacks while into it, after 0.5s she's already stealthed and you have such a little window to counter attack her that it's like there's none.

Really, who the fuck thought that an ability like that was okay for this game, especially on an assassin? Akali is so fucking hard to kill after 6 because she can just press W and hey you can't do shit about her except trying to hit skillshots like you're blind.

Removing its duration extension would be a step in the right direction.

replies.body: I remember when pink wards were actually useful and revealed bullshit stealth.
Yeah Riot was like "stealth had too much counterplay". So they decided it better have 0.

Say you play ADCs, would you be ok with a 75 gold item that creates a field that makes all enemy basic attacks miss? People would buy it every game against you and plop it down whenever you tried to fight, so your main strength and what your kit is balanced around is gone. Since everyone buys this anti-AA ward Riot has to buff your abilities by a ton since it's expected you can't AA. That means that in low Elo where people don't buy it every game your champion is obscenely powerful since you have both powerful abilities and your basic attacks, while in high Elo you only have your abilities.
That's how stealth and pink wards used to work. Stealth champions had to be balanced around not being able to use their stealth, so they'd have to be more powerful than they should since they essentially lacked the vital part of their kit. That meant that when you didn't buy a pink ward you were in for a bad time.
Can we not pretend that that's a good analogy?

They could've made pink wards turn on their reveal invisible passive after a few (let's say 3) seconds to discourage in fight reveals and encourage preemptive warding.
Could've made pink wards have normal vision but the reveal range be lower.
Could've had made pink wards reveal directional (like vision plant is) so it reveals in the straight direction away from you when you first placed it to encourage smart warding(you have to place it towards where you think the invisible guy is coming from).

But no, let's just make invisibility have no counters at all because why bother balancing things.

What kinda comparison is this... 
Pink wards haven't been made to specifically unstealth any champions, they have been made to give some sort of vision controll field, what you suggest is basically a ward purely made to counter champions.

>J Eevo (EUNE)  - about 7 hours ago
They could've made pink wards turn on their reveal invisible passive after a few (let's say 3) seconds to discourage in fight reveals and encourage preemptive warding.

> But no, let's just make invisibility have no counters at all because why bother balancing things.

what Eevo said is a perfect example of the flaw of removing the stealth invisibility totally, it was too oppressive? Fine, the wards purpose was not to reveal champs, so make that extra part a bit weaker, why remove it entirely?

I mean, maybe this isn't the right thread to express this opinion but stealth DID have too much counterplay tbh. If there was a 75 gold item that countered any other class people would go berserk, but against assassins it stuck around a long time. You can't design a stealth champion around stealth when it can be completely invalidated by an item that costs virtually nothing that every character has access to. That would be like a 75 gold Poppy shield that covered half the screen and stayed until people put 5 auto attacks onto it, it would invalidate all dash characters and be absolutely obscene. Since everyone had access to it you could call it "balanced" but all it did was invalidate a game mechanic, and not in a cool TF ultimate or Lulu E way that could be a counterplay to put True Sight on someone.
Who else but ~~Quagmire~~ CertainlyT could design such bad champions?

#Bring On The Salt

The ability is incredibly overloaded-
Energy return
True stealth
Duration increase
Passive interaction
Massive aoe
Movespeed boost.

Akali needs less power in this skill and more power elsewhere (e needs an ap ratio for example...).

That's not overloaded. Hell, "Duration increase" and "Passive Interaction" are stretches. If you wanted it to be overloaded, you'd add an Ally MS boost and a slow on enemies. At that point, it'd be doing too much. But as of the moment, it doesn't. It just enables Akali to play with her kit, that's all it does in the long run.

If you want Overloaded, look at Ekko's W ability: It stuns and shields Ekko, slows enemy in the zone, and has a passive that deals %missing health damage (or something). Right there, it can zone, stun, help allies catch up with the slow, and enables Ekko to safely get into a trade.

Not overloaded?  The ability has three main effects: stealth, movespeed increase, and energy restoration.  That's already plenty enough for a basic ability.  Then on top of that it has: the ability to make it last longer, the ring expands over time, and she can mark it with her E.  SIX EFFECTS IN ONE ABILITY.  How is that not overloaded?

You can have a complicated ability, and not have it overloaded. An overloaded ability is an ability that does too many jobs. Minor Example, Fiora's Ult. On-top of being a massive damage buff to her through having 4 readily available procs, if you kill the target who hit each one, you get a massive heal. 

In this example, the ability is achieving two goals: It's increasing Fiora's damage, and it can heal her team. It has two jobs. Akali's ability, does one thing, and one thing only. It helps herself. It does this through various ways, but it helps her and only her. Her teammates are not beniffited by her using that ability, nor is it going to hamper an enemy into getting caught by teammates, like a slow would. It has a single job. 

Once again, look at my example of Ekko's W. It can be utility to a team, ensure a safer trade for himself, or act as zoning. It does a lot of jobs, and that's not even mentioning it's passive.

So doing two things makes an ability overloaded?  Okay, Lux W can shield herself, but it can also shield her allies.  WoW, So oVeRlOaDeD.  Rakan Q benefits both him and his allies, is that ability overloaded???  "Helping yourself" can be hundreds of different things, but according to you they're all the same.  Akali is helped by her W in SIX FUCKING WAYS.  Plus you could easily just say that the shroud can zone enemies, boom, now it fits your extremely stupid definition of overloaded.

Overloaded means that the ability just does too much, which I agree Ekko's W is a great example of.  It slows, it gives Ekko a shield, and it stuns enemy champs that are in it when Ekko receives the shield.  That's still only three things, although those three are very powerful.  Akali's W does three main things that are pretty much just as strong as any of the individual parts of Ekko's, and then also has three other niche effects on top of that.  Ekko's W is certainly more POWERFUL, but they are both incredibly overloaded.

I said two jobs, not two things. I also said, a Minor Example, since I wanted to get across what "Doing multiple jobs is". Two *separate* jobs. Your 'examples' of my flawed logic all fit in the same category, since they're meant to be support-like abilities, that are sub-par on their own, but better with teammates by their very nature. They don't do two jobs. They do one.

That is my point. An overloaded ability does *multiple* jobs, not multiple things. Don't get pedantic with me.

How about we simplify that

Energy Return
Location Based True Stealth
Movespeed boost.

You can make anything sound overpowered quite easily.

Wait, what?  There’s no way that Akali should kill Anivia unless she badly misplays.  Anivia can ult the shroud and make Akali either back off, take damage, or all-in.  If Akali backs off, then she loses minions.  If Akali takes too much damage, then she can’t risk an all-in.  If Akali goes all-in immediately, then Anivia can just dodge the E skillshot or Q-Q Akali when she dives after it.

And then Akali is just screwed.  Anivia can drop her wall to force her ult or, with proper placement and positioning, keep her stuck in the storm while Anivia pelts her with E and basic attacks.  And even if Akali somehow manages to outplay all that, Anivia still has her egg and can opt into Stopwatch at 10 minutes.

There’s a reason that Anivia _thrives_ in Assassin metas.
They need to increase the time it takes her to restealth when she reveals herself so you can at least hit her back. You know, counterplay.
